author: By John McManus and Iman Al-Dabbagh
title: Qatar’s Most Popular Sport Isn’t What You Think It Is
description: In a World Cup year, the tiny Gulf nation has become synonymous with soccer. But the game of choice for the South Asian workers who help keep the state running is cricket.
content: DOHA, Qatar — If you need to buy a cricket bat here, everyone tells you the same thing:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Varia Bortsova
title: Russia Will Remake Itself. But It Has to Crumble First.
description: We will rebuild Russia, of course, slowly and patiently, just like the generation before us. But not before this one crumbles first.
content: When the first McDonald’s restaurant appeared in the Soviet Union in 1990, my parents bundled my 9-month-old sister up and waited in line for hours in the brisk Russian winter so that they could get their first taste of a Big Mac and those famed French fries. The line snaked all around Moscow’s iconic Pushkin Square: Reports say that 30,000 people showed up on opening day alone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Isn’t Ready if Covid Surges, Scientists Warn
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 20, 2022.
content: “You use the quiet periods to do the hard work. You don’t use the quiet to forget.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘CODA’ Wins Producers Guild Award, Clearing a Path to Best Picture
description: The prize is considered the best bellwether for the Oscars, though the Apple TV+ film still faces stiff competition from “The Power of the Dog.”
content: Is “CODA” the little movie that could?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Basic Instinct’ at 30: A Time Capsule That Can Still Offend
description: The erotic thriller starring Michael Douglas and Sharon Stone was a big hit that set off protests in its day, and it’s easy to see why even now.
content: If you’d like a quick snapshot of how much the tastes of the moviegoing public have changed in the past 30 years, reflect on this. The biggest film of March 1992 was “Basic Instinct,” an erotic thriller featuring an established movie star in explicit onscreen couplings with a sexy up-and-comer. It arrived in theaters preceded by months of controversy and hype, became the hot topic around water coolers and in newspaper editorials, and grossed an astonishing $352 million worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 20, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 20, 2022.
content: An article on Page 5 this weekend about composer Heather Christian’s choral piece “Oratorio for Living Things” misstates Christian’s age. She is 40, not 41.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: ‘Sanditon,’ Unfinished No More
description: After the TV adaptation of an uncompleted Jane Austen novel was canceled after one season, it was saved by a passionate fan campaign and a successful run on PBS.
content: “Charlotte, are you not excited to be returning?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: War Brings Out Solidarity and Defiance in Ukrainians Who Remain
description: About two million people have stayed in Kyiv, a population galvanized by a newfound unity and its refusal to be cowed by Russian invaders.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The historic center of Kyiv, usually bustling with tourists and souvenir stalls around its pastel-colored buildings and golden domed churches, is largely deserted these days. Shops and offices are closed, and the city, placed under curfew from 8 p.m., falls dark and silent at night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: After the ‘Trailer,’ the Blue Jays Are Excited About Their ‘Movie’
description: By adding Matt Chapman, a team on the rise might have the best infield in baseball. The goal: Win the World Series.
content: DUNEDIN, Fla. — The Toronto Blue Jays were one of the most electrifying teams in Major League Baseball last season. They relied on young, vibrant and dynamic players, from first baseman Vladimir Guerrero Jr. to shortstop Bo Bichette to pitcher Alek Manoah. Seven players hit at least 20 home runs. They had the year’s American League Cy Young Award winner (Robbie Ray) and the runner-up for the Most Valuable Player Award (Guerrero). They won 91 games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Fauci predicts an uptick in U.S. cases, saying it is not yet time to ‘declare victory.’
description: President Biden’s top adviser on Covid noted that indoor masking and other restrictions were lifted before latest E.U. surge.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the Biden administration’s top adviser on the pandemic, predicted on Sunday an “uptick” in coronavirus infections similar to the current increase in Europe, despite the current decline in cases, hospitalizations and deaths in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames, Adam Zagoria and Scott Miller
title: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament: Duke Keeps Krzyzewski’s Last Season Alive
description: Duke survived a scare against Michigan State in a battle of two celebrated coaches, Mike Krzyzewski and Tom Izzo. Arizona needed overtime to get past Texas Christian. Houston, Villanova, Texas Tech and Iowa State also advanced to the round of 16.
content: Some of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament’s best moments are birthed from classic David and Goliath matchups. The Goliaths, those powerhouse programs that make deep tournament runs seem routine, meet the Davids, the upstart challengers that many college basketball fans know nothing about until March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Its offensive slowed, Russia uses long-range missiles to devastating effect.
description: Even as the Russian ground advance on key targets including Kyiv and Odessa remains stalled, it has used long-range rockets in recent days to devastating effect against the Ukrainian military and infrastructure.
content: Even as the Russian ground advance on key targets including Kyiv and Odessa remains stalled, it has used long-range rockets in recent days to devastating effect against the Ukrainian military and infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
title: Brazil Lifts Its Ban on Telegram After Two Days
description: Brazil’s Supreme Court blocked Telegram on Friday. The messaging app then responded with measures to fight misinformation, and the court quickly lifted its ban.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s Congress, Supreme Court, election officials and federal police have been trying to get a response from Telegram, the fast-growing messaging app, for months. It turned out, all they had to do was ban it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman
title: Ashley Biden’s Diary Was Shown at Trump Fund-Raiser. Weeks Later, Project Veritas Called Her.
description: The right-wing group’s deceptive call to the president’s daughter a month before Election Day is among the new details that show how the organization worked to expose personal information about the Biden family.
content: A month before the 2020 election, Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s daughter, Ashley, received a call from a man offering help. Striking a friendly tone, the man said that he had found a diary that he believed belonged to Ms. Biden and that he wanted to return it to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood
title: Religion-Fueled Mobs on the Rise Again in Pakistan
description: The recent lynching of a man accused of burning pages from a Quran underscored Pakistan’s leading status as a site of religious violence.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Last month, a man named Muhammad Mushtaq was accused of burning pages of the Quran inside a mosque in central Pakistan. A mob armed with sticks, bricks and axes gathered at the mosque and dragged him out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: ‘I Don’t Have the Right to Cry’: Ukrainian Women Share Their Stories of Escape
description: In war, things can change quickly. A New York Times reporter wanted to capture — in whatever blurry way one can in a war — this moment in this war, three weeks in.
content: In war, things can change quickly. You look away and the kaleidoscope has turned. Suddenly the greens click out of view and the reds have taken their place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Can Ashish Jha, ‘a Comforting Voice,’ Tamp Down Covid’s Political Divide?
description: Dr. Jha, the new White House coronavirus response coordinator, has built a reputation as a gifted communicator, but there is much more to the job.
content: WASHINGTON — For the past two years, as the coronavirus has wreaked havoc on American lives and the world at large, Dr. Ashish K. Jha has been there to make sense of it all. He has been hard to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: No New Taxes, but Plenty to Fight Over in New York’s Looming Budget
description: Potential changes to the state’s bail laws and the extension of mayoral control of schools in New York City are among the issues that await state leaders.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — The yearly race to cobble together New York State’s gargantuan budget is officially on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: ‘The Hours’ Will Bring Renée Fleming Back to the Met
description: Kevin Puts’s new opera had its premiere in a Philadelphia Orchestra concert presentation before coming to New York this fall.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Three women are left alone onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: On Cannabis in Oakland: The ‘Most Important Kind of Story That We Do’
description: As equity models continue to shape recreational cannabis markets, a Times reporter checked to see how one initiative has fared. Behind an article is a network of reporting.
content: When California legalized cannabis for recreational use in 2016, state lawmakers announced their intention to build racial and social equity into the marketplace, to help communities upended by the ravages of the war on drugs. Few cities embraced that drive more than Oakland, which since 2017 has granted cannabis retail licenses to 282 equity applicants, as they are known. That number includes many Black and Hispanic entrepreneurs from neighborhoods with a high number of cannabis-related arrests or who had been charged with a cannabis offense themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How the ‘Whole Life’ Movement Challenges the Politics of Left vs. Right
description: A conversation about a coalition that combines opposition to abortion with advocacy for health care access and a living wage.
content: I was in college, just old enough to vote, when I first bumped into the left-right binary of American politics. I was volunteering with undocumented immigrants, and particularly passionate about the alleviation of poverty, so I was drawn to progressive student groups. But I was also pro-life and involved in more conservative religious groups on campus. My friends and I often felt like we didn’t fit anywhere politically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
title: Truth Is Another Front in Putin’s War
description: The Kremlin has used a barrage of increasingly outlandish falsehoods to prop up its overarching claim that the invasion of Ukraine is justified.
content: In the tense weeks before Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, Russian officials denied that it planned anything of the sort, denouncing the United States and its NATO allies for stoking panic and anti-Russian hatred. When it did invade, the officials denied it was at war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Oscars Rewind: The Last Time Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg Went Head-to-Head
description: The filmmakers are nominated for best director this year, just as they were in 1994. Back then, there wasn’t a clear favorite.
content: If the best director matchup at the Academy Awards next Sunday looks familiar, you aren’t hallucinating: On a warm spring night in Los Angeles in 1994, Jane Campion and Steven Spielberg, who are nominated this year for “The Power of the Dog” and “West Side Story,” went head-to-head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: On Eve of Confirmation Hearings, G.O.P. Steps Up Attacks on Jackson
description: The White House and Democrats have pushed back hard against new claims that the judge was overly lenient in certain cases, calling them a smear.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans are intensifying their attacks on Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson after weeks of publicly reserving judgment on President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee, ahead of historic hearings on the first Black woman to be put forward as a justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Ukraine War Threatens to Cause a Global Food Crisis
description: A critical share of the world’s food and fertilizer is stuck in Russia and Ukraine, sending global prices soaring and foreshadowing a rise in world hunger.
content: The war in Ukraine has delivered a shock to global energy markets. Now the planet is facing a deeper crisis: a shortage of food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Russia Is Losing Tens of Thousands of Outward-Looking Young Professionals
description: Many of them have been streaming into Armenia, where they can work I.T. jobs remotely, at least for a while. At cafes in the capital, Yerevan, the exiles try to plot out new lives from their laptops.
content: YEREVAN, Armenia — At the Lumen cafe in the Armenian capital, Russians arrive as soon as the doors open, ordering specialty coffees, opening up their sleek Apple laptops and trying to navigate a dwindling array of options for starting their lives over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
description: Russian forces made significant gains in Ukraine, advancing into the port of Mariupol, destroying an underground weapons depot and leaving a barracks in ruins following one of the deadliest rocket strikes on Ukraine’s military in the nearly month-old war.
content: Russian forces made significant gains in Ukraine, advancing into the port of Mariupol, destroying an underground weapons depot and leaving a barracks in ruins following one of the deadliest rocket strikes on Ukraine’s military in the nearly month-old war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Revered Jewish Sage Buried in One of the Largest Gatherings in Israel’s History
description: Hundreds of thousands of Israelis shut down large parts of central Israel to attend the funeral of Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, an influential spiritual leader.
content: JERUSALEM — Hundreds of thousands of Israelis gathered on Sunday at the funeral of Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, a spiritual leader in ultra-Orthodox Judaism, in one of the largest public gatherings in Israeli history. Rabbi Kanievsky died on Friday, aged 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Suitable for All Ages
description: John Ewbank and Jeff Chen are in perfect harmony.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Welcome to the Monday crossword, a (mostly) gentle puzzle suitable for all ages, created for us this week by John Ewbank and Jeff Chen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Catherine Porter
title: Russia Broadens Mariupol Assault as Signs of Stalemate Take Shape
description: The battle for Mariupol has become a grim symbol of Russia’s superior firepower and its frustration in failing to subjugate Ukraine after more than three weeks of war.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Firing rockets and bombs from the land, air and — probably for the first time — from warships in the Sea of Azov, Russian forces broadened their bombardment of the besieged Ukrainian city of Mariupol on Sunday and have forcibly deported thousands of residents, according to city officials and witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and David Montgomery
title: Weather Conditions Continue to Fuel Texas Fires
description: Two firefighters were injured fighting a blaze on Sunday, and more evacuations were ordered.
content: Fueled by unfavorable weather conditions, wildfires forced the evacuations of more areas in Central Texas on Sunday, fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Is Taiwan Next?
description: China is watching Russia’s invasion of Ukraine closely.
content: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has amplified fears that the world is teetering back to a Cold War-like era in which the most powerful countries compete for dominance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Hillsong Church Says Brian Houston, Its Founder, Breached Code of Conduct
description: The board of the global megachurch, which got its start in Australia, apologized “unreservedly” to two women who had accused Mr. Houston of inappropriate behavior.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Hillsong, the global megachurch that cultivated an image of cool, urban Christianity for years, has apologized “unreservedly” to two women who had accused the church’s Australian founder, Brian Houston, of inappropriate behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia’s Assault on Mariupol
description: Plus China’s new Covid strategy and concerns of world hunger.
content: With Russia failing to seize major Ukrainian cities, appearing to lose ground around Kyiv and beset by significant losses, there is an emerging consensus in the West that the war has reached a stalemate. However, the fierce fighting in Mariupol continued on Sunday from the land, air and sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: It’s Now Putin’s Plan B in Ukraine vs. Biden’s and Zelensky’s Plan A
description: Russia’s strategic choices could become increasingly frightening to the West.
content: After a confusing month, it is now clear what strategies are playing out in Ukraine: We’re watching Vladimir Putin’s plan B versus Joe Biden’s and Volodymyr Zelensky’s plans A. Let us hope that Biden and Zelensky triumph, because Putin’s potential plan C is really scary — and I don’t even want to write what I fear would be his plan D.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shauna Farnell
title: Former Paralympic Coach Comes ‘Full Circle’ After Losing a Leg
description: Jon Kreamelmeyer, whose right leg was amputated last year, prefers to see it as a transformation rather than a disability.
content: FRISCO, Colo. — In a different world, Jon Kreamelmeyer, 75, would have been in Canada competing in the Masters World Cup of cross-country skiing last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: As Omicron Surges and Economy Suffers, China Tweaks ‘Zero Covid’
description: Beijing is fine-tuning its virus response playbook to try to limit the cost of restrictions. But its goal of eliminating all infections could make that difficult.
content: When the coronavirus first swept across China in early 2020, the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, declared a “people’s war” against the epidemic, launching what would become a no-holds-barred strategy to eliminate infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Haigh
title: Anne Tyler, Close-Up Artist, Zooms Out for a Novel of Family Rifts
description: In her 24th novel, “French Braid,” Tyler works on a bigger canvas than usual to explore the costs and rewards of family life amid secrets, distance and stifled ambition.
content: FRENCH BRAIDBy Anne Tyler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Demand for This Toad’s Psychedelic Venom Is Booming. Some Warn That’s Bad for the Toad.
description: In a sign of unintended consequences of the psychedelic resurgence, scientists say that the Sonoran desert toad is at risk of population collapse.
content: TUCSON, Ariz. — After multiple combat tours as a Navy SEAL, Marcus Capone tried talk therapy. Brain-injury clinics. Prescription drugs. Nothing worked to ease his crippling depression and anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: The 9/11 Trial: Why Are Plea Bargain Talks Underway?
description: New leadership, an ever receding trial date and pressure to disclose more information about the C.I.A. torture of the accused plotters all contribute.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Pentagon prosecutors have struggled for more than a dozen years to hold the death-penalty trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the accused mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, and his four co-defendants at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Chatting on the Phone With a Friend While Walking Through SoHo’
description: A new routine, a prescient gift and more reader tales of life in New York City during the pandemic in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $625,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brenna Smith and Masha Froliak
title: Russian Soldiers Took Their City, Then Their Homes
description: As Russian forces pushed toward Kyiv, they stormed an apartment complex in a nearby suburb and held residents hostage. Some of it was caught on camera.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — For days, Roman Naumenko and his neighbors at the Pokrovsky apartment complex outside Kyiv had been watching from a few short miles away as Russian forces tried to take over a nearby airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Moritz, Eduardo Medina, Tariro Mzezewa and Richard Fausset
title: 1 Dead and 27 Wounded in Shooting at an Arkansas Car Show
description: The police are still searching for two people they believe engaged in a gunfight that led to the mayhem. Six children were among those injured.
content: DUMAS, Ark. — A community event and car show in a small Arkansas farming community became a scene of horror on Saturday night, as two people engaged in a gunfight and sprayed the crowd with bullets, killing one bystander and injuring 27 other people, including six children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Amid rising cases, Austria hastily reintroduces an indoor mask mandate.
description: Earlier this month, Austrian officials also had announced that the nation’s general vaccine mandate would be temporarily suspended.
content: Austria will reintroduce an indoor mask mandate, the health minister, Johannes Rauch, announced on Friday, bucking a trend among European countries to lift coronavirus precautions despite rising cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: At Harvard, Ketanji Brown Jackson Fought Injustices but Kept a Steely Academic Focus
description: A look at Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s career as a Harvard student shows her early passion for justice, and her strong sense of identity.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When a Confederate flag was hung from the window of a dormitory at Harvard University more than 30 years ago, members of the Black Students Association saw it as an attempt to tell them they did not belong there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: A Younger O’Bannon Plays in a New College Sports Landscape
description: Chuck O’Bannon Jr., a guard for Texas Christian, grew up as his uncle Ed O’Bannon became a symbol for college athletes pushing to earn money from their fame.
content: SAN DIEGO — Dalen Terry, a starting guard for the University of Arizona’s top-seeded team in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, told reporters this week that it was “a dream come true” to see his name on the back of jerseys being sold in the campus bookstore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner and Remy Tumin
title: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament: Iowa and Baylor Fall to No. 10 Seeds
description: In Iowa City, a former Hawkeye delivered the go-ahead shot for Creighton in the fourth quarter. In Texas, South Dakota’s defense slowed down Baylor. Two No. 2 seeds are out of the field.
content: Tenth-seeded Creighton made its first round of 16, and it did it with late-game drama befitting the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Can Eric Adams Cheerlead New Yorkers Past the Pandemic?
description: The mayor is singularly focused on bringing back New York City’s economy, now that coronavirus cases have dropped.
content: Mayor Eric Adams has made no secret of his desire to fast-track New York City’s recovery from the coronavirus, and in his regular briefings with health officials, he has been encouraged by the latest metrics: Cases have greatly receded while vaccination rates have hit nearly 90 percent for adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 21, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Julian Heicklen, Cantankerous Civil Liberties Advocate, Dies at 90
description: A retired chemistry professor, he staged weekly protests in front of a Manhattan courthouse, angering prosecutors, who tried to send him to prison.
content: Julian P. Heicklen, a charismatic, cantankerous chemistry professor who dedicated his retirement years to a series of public protests in defense of civil liberties, culminating in his 2011 indictment for jury tampering, died on March 11 at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Children Can’t Wait’: A Better Path to Reading
description: A discussion about improving reading skills and the education system generally. Also: Scientific discovery.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Celebrate the spring equinox with recipes for Nowruz, then make a menu for the rest of the week.
content: Good morning. It’s Nowruz, the celebration of spring equinox observed in Afghanistan, Iran, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and beyond. We have recipes to celebrate the season and to celebrate the holiday alike.
source.name: The New York Times
